questions.text: A primigravida is in the 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours. The head is at +3 with caput present and the fetal heart rate (FHR) is dropping to 90 bpm. What is the best way to deliver the head? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

In this scenario, the patient is a primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) who is in the second stage of labor, which has been ongoing for 2 hours. The second stage of labor in a primigravida can be allowed up to 3 hours if the mother and fetus are stable. However, in this case, the fetal heart rate has dropped to 90 bpm, indicating fetal distress, and the head is at +3 station, meaning it is very low in the pelvis, almost at the pelvic floor.

 

  • Outlet forceps are specifically designed for situations where the fetal head is at +3 station or lower. The head is visible at the introitus without separating the labia, and delivery needs to be expedited due to fetal distress. In this case, the application of outlet forceps is preferred because it allows for a quicker delivery compared to other methods. This is critical when there is evidence of fetal distress, as time is of the essence to reduce the risk of hypoxia.
  • Mid cavity forceps are used when the fetal head is higher in the pelvis, typically at 0 to +1 station. This option is not suitable in this case because the head is much lower, at +3 station.
  • Low forceps are used when the head is at +2 station, slightly higher than in this scenario. They are not appropriate when the head is at +3 station.
  • Ventouse (vacuum extraction) can be used at various stations, but it is generally slower to apply compared to forceps. Additionally, the presence of caput (swelling of the fetal scalp) can make it difficult to achieve the necessary suction for effective vacuum delivery. Therefore, outlet forceps are preferred in this scenario to ensure a quicker and more effective delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid cavity forceps: Incorrect because they are used when the head is at a higher station, typically 0 to +1, and the head is not yet at the pelvic floor.

 

Option B. Low forceps: Incorrect because they are more suitable when the head is at +2 station, not when it is already at +3 station.

 

Option D. Ventouse (vacuum extraction): While it could technically be used, it is not the best choice here because of the fetal distress and the presence of caput, which may hinder the effective application of the vacuum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of fetal distress with the fetal head at +3 station, outlet forceps are the preferred method of assisted delivery due to their speed and effectiveness, particularly when caput is present.

questions.text: A patient with chronic diarrhea develops dermatitis herpetiformis. The physician altered his diet which improved his symptoms. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. The immune system mistakenly targets gluten, along with the lining of the small intestine, leading to symptoms such as chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and weight loss. One of the hallmark dermatological manifestations of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition presents as a chronic, intensely itchy rash, typically on the elbows, knees, back, and buttocks, and is caused by the deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermoepidermal junction.

 

The improvement of symptoms following the alteration of the patient’s diet to exclude gluten is a classic indicator of celiac disease. Once gluten is removed from the diet, the intestinal inflammation subsides, and symptoms, including dermatitis herpetiformis, typically improve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whipple disease: Whipple disease is a rare bacterial infection that can cause malabsorption, leading to symptoms such as diarrhea and weight loss. However, it does not typically cause dermatitis herpetiformis, nor does dietary modification alone usually lead to symptom improvement.

 

Option C. Crohn disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. However, it does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and dietary changes like removing gluten do not usually lead to the dramatic improvement seen in celiac disease.

 

Option D. Lactose intolerance: Lactose intolerance results from the inability to digest lactose, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy products. It does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and the improvement in symptoms would be related to avoiding dairy, not gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be suspected in patients presenting with chronic diarrhea and dermatitis herpetiformis, particularly when symptoms improve following a gluten-free diet.

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar Nerve Palsy
Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy
Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture
Knuckle bender splint; Median Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly match the statement regarding the splint shown in image:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy

 

  • Cock-up splint is used for radial nerve palsy.

 

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURIES

 

  • Most common nerve damaged in human body.
  • Most common cause: Fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Shaft of Humerus divided into 3 parts:
    • Upper 1/3rd
    • Middle 1/3rd
    • Lower 1/3rd: Radial nerve injured (50%)
       
  • Holstein Lewis sign: Radial nerve injury in lower 1/3rd fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Paralysis of ECRL & ECRB will cause loss of wrist, thumb and finger extension, leading to Wrist drop.
  • Wrist drop occurs in low radial nerve palsy, which spares the elbow and wrist extension.
  • There is also loss of sensation over the dorsum of 1st web space.

 

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment is usually conservative, which includes analgesic medications like NSAIDs; corticosteroid injections; physiotherapy; and immobilization with cock-up splints for 2-4 weeks.
    • The patient recovers within 4 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Option C. Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. Turn buckle splint is used to produce gradual stretching over the contracted joint. It is used to treat stiff elbow and Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.

 

 

Option D. Knuckle bender splint; Median nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question is a dynamic cock-up splint, which is used in cases of radial nerve injuries (wrist drop).

questions.text: Spread of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebra occurs via? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous

 

Explanation:

 

Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through:

 

  • Bateson's venous plexus (vertebral venous plexus)
  • This is a valveless system allowing bidirectional flow
  • Connects prostatic venous plexus to vertebral veins
  • Most common cancer in men with bone metastasis
  • Typically produces osteoblastic lesions in bones

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct: Incorrect as prostate is anatomically distant from lumbar vertebrae making direct spread impossible

 

Option B. Arterial: Incorrect as prostatic venous plexus connection to vertebrae via Bateson's plexus is the established pathway

 

Option D. Lymphatic: Incorrect as lymphatic spread of prostate cancer is typically to pelvic and para-aortic nodes, not directly to vertebrae

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through Bateson's venous plexus, making it the most common cancer in men with bone metastasis.



Spread of CA Prostate

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

 

Hypersensitivity myocarditis

 

 

Giant cell myocarditis

 

 

Myocarditis of Chagas disease (arrow showing trypanosomes)

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with red, scaly rashes around the mouth and anus, a history of chronic diarrhoea, poor wound healing, and growth delay. Based on these symptoms, which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective intestinal absorption of zinc. This condition manifests as perioral, perivaginal, and perianal dermatitis, along with alopecia and diarrhea. Zinc deficiency is common in premature infants, children with malabsorption syndromes, and individuals on prolonged parenteral nutrition without adequate supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper Deficiency: Copper deficiency presents with hypopigmentation, neutropenia, and anemia but does not typically cause a perianal rash.

 

Option B. Selenium Deficiency: Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, which can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy​

 

Option D. Cobalt Deficiency: Cobalt is an essential component of vitamin B12, and its deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, but it does not cause perianal rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency should be suspected in pediatric patients presenting with perianal, perioral, and perivaginal rash, along with diarrhea and growth retardation. The condition, acrodermatitis enteropathica, requires zinc supplementation for treatment.

questions.text: A child presented with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. X ray is shown. Which of the following should be corrected before surgery? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

The X-ray image shows a characteristic "single bubble" sign, which is indicative of pyloric stenosis or pyloric atresia. In this condition, there is obstruction at the pylorus, leading to recurrent non-bilious vomiting. The continuous vomiting results in significant electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia with hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

 

Hypokalemia is the most critical electrolyte disturbance that needs to be corrected before surgery in these patients. This is because:

 

  1. It's a direct result of the continuous vomiting and loss of potassium-rich gastric contents.
  2. Low potassium levels can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which pose a significant risk during surgery.
  3. Correcting hypokalemia is essential for maintaining proper muscle function, including that of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Incorrect. Pyloric stenosis typically causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: Incorrect. While hyponatremia can occur, hypokalemia is the more urgent concern in this scenario.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: Incorrect. Hypernatremia is not typically associated with pyloric stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pyloric stenosis, characterized by recurrent non-bilious vomiting and a "single bubble" sign on X-ray, hypokalemia is the most critical electrolyte imbalance that must be corrected before surgical intervention.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

A child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor and given radiograph points to a diagnosis of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

 

LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region
  • Caused by Parainfluenza virus
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild Tachypnea

 

Treatment –

 

  • Nebulized racemic adrenaline (1:1 mixture of d & I isomers)
  • A single dose of dexamethasone (0.3--0.6 mg/kg, intramuscular) reduces seventy, if given within the first 24 hours.
  • Antibiotics not indicated

 

NOTE -

 

Croup decreases in lying down position and Laryngomalacia increases on lying down

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis patients, usually 3-6 years of age, present with acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia and drooling. The patient looks toxic and sits in tripod position, sitting upright, leaning forward with chin up. Treatment is IV Ceftriaxone. Lateral neck X-ray reveals thickening of the epiglottis (thumb print sign).

 

 

Option C. Foreign body in glottis: Aspiration of foreign body may result in localized area of wheeze, hyperresonance and reduced air entry. Foreign bodies are removed through a rigid bronchoscope.

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is M/C cause of congenital laryngeal anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

choices.text: Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year

 

Correct sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 cm in the first year.

 

Normal length of a newborn - 48-50cm (increase by 50% at 1st year = 75cm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year: An infant gain weight at a rate of approximately 20-40 g per day for the first 3 months of life. Thereafter, they gain about 400 g weight every month for the remaining part of the first year.

 

Option C. Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age:

 

 

Option D. Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile: According to WHO growth charts, weight and height under 50th percentile do not indicate adequate growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in length by 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine poisoning

 

Gastric lavage, also known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, involves the removal of the stomach's contents via a tube. It is contraindicated in certain situations due to the risks involved.

 

Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine is a convulsive poison. Performing gastric lavage on a patient with strychnine poisoning is highly dangerous because it can induce further convulsions and seizures. Gastric lavage acts as a stimulus, which can exacerbate the convulsions, leading to a higher risk of complications including aspiration of stomach contents into the lungs.

 

Contraindications of gastric lavage:

 

  • Corrosive substances (an absolute C/I): Risk of gastric perforation except for carbolic acid, which hardens the stomach wall.
  • Convulsive patients: Risk of aspiration.
  • Comatose patients: Also at risk of aspiration unless the airway is protected.
  • Kerosene & other volatile poison, including hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons are volatile and can cause chemical pneumonitis if aspirated.
  • Oesophageal Varices

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ingestion of paraldehyde: Paraldehyde ingestion does not have the same risk of inducing convulsions or seizures. Gastric lavage can be considered in some cases, but it is not absolutely contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ingestion of hydrocarbons: Hydrocarbons, such as kerosene, are volatile and pose a high risk of aspiration leading to chemical pneumonitis. While this is also a contraindication, the most critical contraindication here is strychnine poisoning due to the additional risk of inducing seizures.

 

Option D. Iron tablet ingestion: Iron tablets do not pose a high risk of convulsions or severe aspiration. Gastric lavage can be used in cases of iron tablet ingestion if done early and under proper medical supervision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in cases of strychnine poisoning due to the high risk of inducing further convulsions and seizures, which can exacerbate the patient's condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia, and feelings of hopelessness. The patient has a history of a similar episode with full recovery approximately five years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent Depressive Disorder

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder (RDD) is diagnosed when a patient has experienced two or more depressive episodes, with each episode separated by at least two months of remission. In this case, the patient presents with symptoms of a current depressive episode and reports having experienced a similar episode five years ago, with full recovery in between. The presence of more than one depressive episode aligns with the criteria for Recurrent Depressive Disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Major Depressive Disorder: This would be considered if the patient was experiencing their first depressive episode. Since the patient has had a previous depressive episode, the diagnosis is Recurrent Depressive Disorder rather than a single Major Depressive Disorder.

 

Option C. Dysthymia: Also known as Persistent Depressive Disorder, dysthymia is characterized by chronic, mild depressive symptoms that last for at least two years. The patient's symptoms are more severe, consistent with major depressive episodes rather than mild chronic symptoms, which rules out dysthymia.

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: Cyclothymia involves periods of hypomanic symptoms and mild depressive (bipolar) symptoms over at least two years, but the symptoms do not meet the criteria for a full hypomanic episode or a full depressive episode. The patient's presentation does not include any hypomanic symptoms, making cyclothymia an incorrect diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder is diagnosed when a patient experiences two or more major depressive episodes, separated by periods of remission

questions.text: Identify the condition shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jejunal atresia

 

The image provided shows the classic "triple bubble" sign, which is characteristic of jejunal atresia. In this condition, there are three distinct bubbles visible on the radiograph: the stomach, the proximal duodenum, and the distal duodenum. This occurs because the blockage is located at the level of the jejunum, causing dilatation of the preceding segments of the intestine.

 

Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where a portion of the jejunum is absent or closed, leading to obstruction. This results in the accumulation of air and fluid in the segments of the intestine proximal to the obstruction, creating the appearance of multiple bubbles on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small bowel obstruction: Typically presents with multiple air-fluid levels throughout the bowel, rather than the distinct "bubble" signs seen in jejunal atresia.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Characterized by the "double bubble" sign, where only two bubbles are visible: one in the stomach and one in the proximal duodenum. The third bubble seen in the image rules out duodenal atresia.

 

Option D. CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis): Presents with a single bubble on the radiograph, representing a dilated stomach. The pyloric stenosis prevents stomach contents from passing into the duodenum, leading to a single dilated stomach bubble.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "triple bubble" sign is indicative of jejunal atresia, where three dilated segments are visible on the radiograph: the stomach, proximal duodenum, and distal duodenum. This sign is crucial for differentiating jejunal atresia from other types of intestinal obstructions like duodenal atresia or small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G2P1

 

Explanation:

 

  • The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history as follows:
    • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
    • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages
    • L - Living children.
  • The GTPAL system includes the following:
    • Gravida
    • Term (>37 weeks)
    • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
    • Abortions (<20 weeks)
    • Number of living children

 

Obstetric Score

 

  • Gravidity:
    • G2 (Second pregnancy)
  • Parity:
    • P1 (One previous pregnancy reaching viability, twins count as one para)

 

So, the correct obstetric score for this lady is G2P1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gravida denotes the number of pregnancies, and para denotes the number of pregnancies reaching the period of viability. Twins count as one in the para score, and the current pregnancy is included in gravida but not in para until delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The type of pelvis commonly associated with occipitoposterior and face to pubis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by a larger anteroposterior diameter compared to its transverse diameter, giving it a vertical oval shape. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern, where the baby's face presents toward the pubic symphysis during delivery. The anthropoid shape often causes the baby's head to rotate into a posterior position, leading to a higher likelihood of occipitoposterior presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the typical female pelvis with a round shape and balanced anteroposterior and transverse diameters. It is most favorable for vaginal deliveries and is not commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions.

 

Option B. Android pelvis: The android pelvis is heart-shaped, narrower, and typically has prominent ischial spines. It is more commonly associated with obstructed labor and deep transverse arrest rather than occipitoposterior or face to pubis presentations.

 

Option D. Platypelloid pelvis: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a very wide transverse diameter and a flat shape, which often leads to delayed engagement of the fetal head. It is not associated with occipitoposterior positions but can lead to asynclitism and face presentations.

 

Educational Objective:


The anthropoid pelvis is the pelvic type most commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern.

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance.

 

TAPVC:

 

  • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation.
  • It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.

 

The following types are seen:

 

I. Supra cardiac – Most common type

II. Cardiac

III. Infra cardiac – Most common type for obstruction (worst prognosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial trunk coming from the heart, not typically showing a snowman sign.

 

Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition typically shows an "egg on a string" appearance due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.

 

Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Characterized by a boot-shaped heart on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy; not the pattern observed in this image.'

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "snowman sign" on a chest X-ray in a child presenting with cyanosis and fatigue is highly suggestive of Supracardiac TAPVC.

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a corrective lens with the following prescription: -1D spherical, -2D cylinder at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error is being corrected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) With the rule astigmatism

 

  • In the context of refractive errors corrected by lenses, here's an explanation of each type of astigmatism as mentioned:

 

In this condition, the eye's steepest curve is oriented vertically (up and down). This is the most common type of astigmatism. The -2D cylindrical correction at 180 degrees indicates that the correction is applied horizontally, which compensates for the steeper vertical curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Against the Rule Astigmatism: Here, the steepest curvature is horizontal (side to side). Corrective lenses for this type would have cylindrical axes oriented vertically (usually at 90 degrees).

 

Option C. Simple Astigmatism: This occurs when one principal meridian is emmetropic (normal), meaning no refractive error, while the other has myopia (short-sightedness) or hyperopia (long-sightedness). There is only one refractive error to correct.

 

Option D. Mixed Astigmatism: This type features one meridian with myopia and the perpendicular meridian with hyperopia. Essentially, one axis is near sighted, and the other is farsighted, requiring complex lens corrections to address both issues simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When prescribed corrective lenses for astigmatism, understanding the orientation and type of astigmatism (with the rule, against the rule, simple, or mixed) is crucial for ensuring the correct lens type and orientation is used, thus maximizing visual clarity and health.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with increased thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination. He has no other symptoms. His random blood sugar was 205 mg/dl, what appropriate investigations should be done? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. HbA1c
  2. Urine ACR
  3. Echocardiography
  4. Fundoscopy
  5. ECG
  6. Serum protein electrophoresis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) i, ii, iv, v

 

The patient presents with hyperglycemia (random blood sugar of 205 mg/dl), indicating diabetes. The appropriate investigations for a newly diagnosed diabetic patient are:

 

1. HbA1c: To assess long-term glycemic control and confirm the diagnosis of diabetes.

 

2. Urine ACR (Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio): To screen for diabetic nephropathy, as microalbuminuria is an early sign of kidney damage.

 

4. Fundoscopy: To check for diabetic retinopathy and other microvascular changes in the eyes.

 

5. ECG: To screen for any cardiovascular complications, as diabetes increases the risk of heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Echocardiography: Not a routine screening test for diabetes unless there is a specific indication, such as suspected heart failure or structural heart disease.

 

6. Serum protein electrophoresis: Not indicated in the routine evaluation of diabetes and is used to diagnose conditions like multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a newly diagnosed diabetic patient, essential investigations include HbA1c, urine ACR, fundoscopy, and ECG to assess glycemic control, kidney function, eye health, and cardiovascular risk, respectively.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to bowing of the legs. On examination, the child has widening of the wrists and frontal bossing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

Bowing of the legs in a 2-year-old child is most commonly associated with rickets, a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency leading to defective bone mineralization​

 

Features of Rickets:

 

  • Bowing of legs (genu varum) in toddlers
  • Widening of wrists
  • Delayed fontanelle closure
  • Frontal bossing
  • Rachitic rosary (prominent costochondral junctions)
  • Harrison sulcus (groove in the lower rib cage due to diaphragmatic pull)
  • Growth retardation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Caused by vitamin C deficiency, presenting with bleeding gums, corkscrew hairs, and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not bowing of legs.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Congenital syphilis can cause saber shins (anterior bowing of tibia), but it is less common and usually presents with other stigmata like Hutchinson’s teeth and saddle nose deformity.

 

Option D. Anemia: Does not cause bowing of the legs. Iron-deficiency anemia may cause fatigue and pallor but does not affect bone structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickets should be suspected in children with bowing of the legs, delayed fontanelle closure, and widened wrists. It is caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to defective bone mineralization.

questions.text: What is given to prevent neural tube defects? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Folic acid

 

Folic acid supplementation is essential for the prevention of neural tube defects (NTDs) in the developing fetus. Neural tube defects are severe birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly, that occur when the neural tube does not close completely. Folic acid, a B-vitamin, significantly reduces the risk of these defects when taken in adequate amounts before conception and during early pregnancy.

 

It is recommended that women start taking folic acid atleast three months before conception and continue through the first three months of pregnancy.

 

For women at low risk, the recommended dose is 0.4 to 0.5 mg per day.

 

For those at high risk, including women with a previous pregnancy affected by NTDs, known folate deficiency, overt diabetes mellitus, or those on anti-epileptic drugs, the recommended dose is 4 to 5 mg per day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: This option is incorrect as iron supplementation is used primarily to prevent and treat anemia in pregnancy, not to prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option B. Calcium: This is incorrect because calcium is important for the development of the fetal skeletal system and for maternal bone health, but it does not prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: This option is incorrect as vitamin B12, while important for overall neurological health, is not the primary supplement used to prevent neural tube defects. However, B12 works synergistically with folic acid, and deficiency in B12 can contribute to NTDs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy is crucial to prevent neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

 

This is the correct answer. Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that contains FAD as a prosthetic group and plays a significant role in the reduction of glutathione disulfide (GSSG) to glutathione (GSH). The activity of glutathione reductase, which depends on the availability of FAD, can be used to assess tissue riboflavin (FAD precursor) status. Therefore, measuring the activity of glutathione reductase with and without FAD is a method for assessing FAD status in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is not directly involved in determining FAD status. Thiamine plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism but doesn't directly influence the levels of FAD in the body.

 

Option C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in the first step of glucose metabolism, but it is not responsible for determining FAD status.

 

Option D. Transketolase: Transketolase is marker enzyme for B1 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAD is the active form of Vitamin B2 and marker for the B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent migraines characterized by throbbing unilateral headaches, nausea, and photophobia. She has not responded to over-the-counter analgesics. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for acute treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

 

Explanation:

 

Sumatriptan is the most appropriate choice for acute migraine treatment. It belongs to the triptan class (5-HT₁B/1D receptor agonists) and:

 

  • Works through vasoconstriction and blocking pain pathways
  • Most effective when taken early in a migraine attack

 

The patient presents with classic migraine symptoms (unilateral throbbing headache, nausea, photophobia) and has failed over-the-counter medications, making triptans the next step in management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Incorrect. Beta-blocker used for migraine prophylaxis rather than acute treatment

 

Option C. Amitriptyline: Incorrect. Tricyclic antidepressant used for migraine prevention, not acute attacks

 

Option D. Verapamil: Incorrect. Calcium channel blocker used for cluster headache prophylaxis, not migraines

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan) are first-line medications for acute treatment of moderate-to-severe migraines that have not responded to over-the-counter analgesics.

questions.text: Based on the given image, calculate the total percentage of body surface area affected. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-30%

 

Explanation:

 

To calculate burn surface area in this scenario:

 

  • Image shows only anterior burns (no posterior burns mentioned)
  • Total anterior surface = 50% of body surface area

 

Areas involved:

 

  • Half of face and neck (~1%)
  • Partial chest and abdomen (~13-14%)
  • Parts of upper limb (~4-5%)
  • Parts of thigh (~4-5%)

 

Approximate calculation:

 

  • About half of anterior surface is burned
  • Half of 50% = ~25%
  • Therefore, the total burn area falls in 20-30% range

 

While Lund and Browder charts are more accurate for children, this approximation method gives similar results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10-20%: Incorrect as burns involve significant anterior surface area

 

Option C. 40-50%: Incorrect as only anterior burns are present, not circumferential

 

Option D. 60%: Incorrect as this would indicate extensive circumferential burns

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burn surface area is calculated using the Rule of Nines for adults or the Lund and Browder Chart for children. In the given case, the estimated burn area was 20-30%.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

 

In this case, the injury is localized to the tibial tuberosity, a prominent bony projection on the anterior aspect of the tibia. The tibial tuberosity serves as the attachment point for the patellar ligament. Injuries to this region, especially in young, active individuals (often seen in adolescents), can be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is an osteochondritis of the tibial tuberosity. This condition is common in children and adolescents undergoing growth spurts and is characterized by knee pain, swelling, and tenderness at the tibial tuberosity following physical activity or trauma, such as a fall from stairs.

 

The patient in this question, a 10-year-old with knee pain after a fall, shows signs consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial tubercle: The medial tubercle refers to the medial part of the tibial plateau and is not directly related to the symptoms or the location of the injury in this case.

 

Option C. Gerdy's tubercle: Gerdy's tubercle is the insertion site for the iliotibial band on the lateral side of the tibia. The injury in the image and description does not involve Gerdy's tubercle, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Anterior intercondylar area: This area is located between the condyles of the tibia and is the site of cruciate ligament attachments. However, this is not the structure marked or injured in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease, characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl has a greyish white membrane over tonsils and presented with bull-neck appearance. She has a 2-year-old brother who is fully immunized for his age. What should be given to the brother? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Nothing should be given

 

The 5-year-old girl shows clinical signs of diphtheria, characterized by a greyish white membrane over the tonsils and bull-neck appearance. The question asks about the appropriate management for her fully immunized 2-year-old brother, who is a close contact.

 

 

For contacts of a diphtheria case:

 

  • If the contact (in this case, the brother) has received primary immunization or a booster within the last 2 years, no additional intervention is needed.
  • If the immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, then a booster dose is required to maintain protection.
  • If the contact is completely unimmunized – Prophylactic t/t with Penicillin or Erythromycin along with 1000-2000 units Diphtheria antitoxin, and start immunization of contact

 

Medical surveillance needs to be done daily and

 

Bacteriological surveillance – swabs on weekly basis 

 

Since the brother is fully immunized for his age, and presumably within the past 2 years, no additional treatment is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Penicillin:  This is used as prophylactic treatment for contacts who are completely unimmunized. It is not indicated for those who are fully vaccinated.

 

Option C.  Diphtheria antitoxin: This is administered to unimmunized contacts for immediate passive immunity, especially when there is a high risk of exposure, but it is not required for fully immunized individuals.

 

Option D.  1 dose of DPT booster:  This is given if the last dose of primary immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, but not needed if within the last 2 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In managing contacts of diphtheria, no additional doses are required if the contact has received primary immunization or booster within the last 2 years.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriche’s syndrome.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

choices.text: Increased discharge of norepinephrine from the locus ceruleus

questions.text: Caffeine is a widely used stimulant that promotes wakefulness. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this effect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine antagonism

 

Caffeine exerts its stimulant effects primarily through the antagonism of adenosine receptors, specifically the A1 receptors in the brain. Adenosine is a neuromodulator that generally promotes sleep and relaxation by inhibiting neuronal activity. By blocking adenosine's action, caffeine prevents this inhibitory effect, leading to increased alertness and wakefulness.

 

Caffeine’s ability to keep you awake and alert is also related to its secondary effects, including the release of norepinephrine from the locus ceruleus and inhibition of phosphodiesterase, which increases cyclic AMP levels. However, the primary mechanism responsible for promoting wakefulness is the antagonism of adenosine receptors.

 

Remember - Side effects of ADEnosine antagonism:

 

  • A for Arrhythmias
  • D for Diuresis
  • E for Epileptic seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased discharge of norepinephrine from the locus ceruleus: While caffeine can increase the release of norepinephrine, which is involved in alertness and arousal, this is not the primary mechanism for its wakefulness-promoting effects.

 

Option C. Release of histamine: Histamine release is associated with wakefulness, but this is not a direct mechanism of action for caffeine. Histamine release is more associated with other pathways in the brain.

 

Option D. Inhibition of phosphodiesterase: Caffeine does inhibit phosphodiesterase, leading to increased levels of cyclic AMP, but this mechanism is more relevant to its cardiovascular and smooth muscle effects rather than its role in promoting wakefulness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caffeine is a widely used stimulant that promotes wakefulness through three main mechanisms:

 

  1. Inhibits phosphodiesterase enzyme.
  2. Acts as an adenosine A1 receptor antagonist.
  3. Releases norepinephrine from the locus coeruleus.

 

Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily through the antagonism of adenosine receptors, blocking the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine and resulting in increased alertness

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the clinical pediatric case as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate

 

 

 

The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which is a tumor located at the base of the coccyx in newborns. It is the most common tumor in neonates, and its origin and characteristics are well understood.

 

  • Persistence of Primitive Streak: Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak, not from the prochordal plate. The primitive streak is a structure in early embryonic development that usually regresses, but if remnants persist, they can lead to the formation of these tumors.
  • Defective Migration of Primordial Cells: This statement is correct as primordial germ cells that fail to migrate properly to the genital ridge can contribute to the formation of teratomas.
  • Contains Skin, Cartilage, and Bone: Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Therefore, they can contain a variety of tissue types including skin, cartilage, and bone.
  • Benign Tumor of Coccyx: Sacrococcygeal teratomas are generally benign, although they can sometimes be malignant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge: This statement is correct. Defective migration can result in teratomas.

 

Option C. Contains skin, cartilage, and bone: This statement is correct as teratomas can contain these tissues.

 

Option D. Benign tumor of coccyx: This statement is correct as sacrococcygeal teratomas are often benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak and can contain various tissues including skin, cartilage, and bone. They are typically benign tumors located at the base of the coccyx.

questions.text: The Honorable Supreme Court of India has banned one of the following, which is infamous among doctors for sexual assault cases: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Two finger test

 

The Supreme Court of India has banned the two-finger test, which was infamous in sexual assault cases. The rationale behind the test was that by inserting two fingers into the vagina, the examiner could determine if a woman was "habituated to sex." If two fingers could be inserted, it was assumed that the woman was sexually active; if only one finger could be inserted, it suggested that she was not.

 

This test was criticized for several reasons:

 

  1. Irrelevance to the Current Case: The past sexual behavior of the victim has no bearing on the facts of the current case of sexual assault. The test does not provide any information relevant to determining whether a rape occurred.
  2. Character Judgment: The test was used to infer the character of the woman, which is derogatory and not permissible. It essentially judged the woman based on her sexual history, which is irrelevant and discriminatory.
  3. Psychological Harm: The test could cause additional trauma to the victim, compounding the psychological harm already experienced due to the assault.

 

The Supreme Court's ruling emphasized that the past sexual behavior of a woman should not be documented or examined as it has no relevance to the current case of rape. The focus should be on the incident in question, not on the victim's sexual history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheter insertion: This is a medical procedure used to drain the bladder and is unrelated to assessing sexual history or assault.

 

Option B. Colposcopy: This is a medical diagnostic procedure to examine an illuminated, magnified view of the cervix and the tissues of the vagina and vulva. It is used in cases of abnormal Pap smears and is not used for determining past sexual behavior.

 

Option C. PV speculum: The use of a speculum is part of a gynecological exam to inspect the vaginal and cervical areas. It is a routine medical examination tool and does not relate to assessing sexual history or habits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The two-finger test, previously used to assess whether a woman was "habituated to sex," has been banned by the Supreme Court of India due to its irrelevance, discriminatory nature, and potential to cause additional trauma to sexual assault victims.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary crystals as shown in the image below. What can be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethylene Glycol

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine. When ethylene glycol is ingested, it undergoes metabolic conversion in the body to glycoaldehyde, which is then converted to glycolic acid, glyxolyic acid, and finally oxalic acid. Oxalic acid combines with calcium in the body to form calcium oxalate crystals. These crystals are excreted in the urine and can cause significant renal damage, potentially leading to renal failure. Additionally, the formation of calcium oxalate crystals depletes calcium levels in the body, leading to symptoms of hypocalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methyl Alcohol: Methyl alcohol, or methanol, is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid, which primarily cause metabolic acidosis and visual disturbances. It does not lead to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

 

Option C. Aconite: Aconite poisoning affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, causing symptoms such as hypotension, arrhythmias, and paresthesias. It does not result in the formation of urinary crystals.

 

Option D. Organophosphate poisoning: Organophosphate poisoning affects the nervous system by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine. Symptoms include muscle twitching, respiratory distress, and bradycardia. It does not cause calcium oxalate crystals to form in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning leads to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, which can cause renal failure and hypocalcemia

questions.text: Best test for the diagnosis of disease malaria species is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

 

  • The image shown in the question is of high-stepping gait, where the foot drops due to common peroneal nerve injury and while walking, the foot slaps on the ground.

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is one of the two major branches of the sciatic nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The innervation of the superficial peroneal nerve are:
    • Motor:
      • Peroneus longus
      • Peroneus brevis
    • Sensory: Anterolateral leg
  • Deep peroneal nerve innervation are:
    • Motor:
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
    • Sensory: First dorsal webspace
  • The nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck.
  • The most common presentation of a common peroneal nerve injury is a weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and the classic resultant foot drop while ambulating. 
  • Foot drop can develop acutely or over days to weeks, depending on the etiology. It can also be complete or partial in severity.
  • There may also be accompanying numbness or paresthesia present along the lateral leg, dorsal foot, and/or the first toe webspace.
  • Pain may also be present in traumatic cases but is not always present.
  • A patient with weakened or paralyzed dorsiflexors may ambulate with a high steppage gait to prevent dragging of toes on the ground.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Waddling gait. Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, like in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture of the hip joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients have difficulty in standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase. This waddling gait pattern can also be caused when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck. 

 

 

Option C. Circumduction gait. Also called as Hemiplegic gait, circumduction gait is most commonly seen in stroke. The patient stands with unilateral weakness on the affected side with arm flexed, adducted and internally rotated. Leg on the same side is in extension with plantar flexion of the foot and toes. While walking, the patient hold their arm to one side and drags the affected leg in semi-circle or circumduction due to weakness of the distal muscles (foot drop) and extensor hypertonia in the lower limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of a painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Syphilis

 

Given scenario points out to a diagnosis of syphilis

 

ACQUIRED SYPHILIS:

 

Mode of acquisition - Sexual transmission & Blood transfusion

 

Stages are as follows –

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: In this condition both genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy are painful. It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, with an incubation period of 2-5 days.

 

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: It causes painful ulcers in the genital region and localized tender lymphadenopathy, caused by HSV 2 > 1.

 

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale (aka donovanosis): It is caused by the bacterium Calymmatobacter / Klebsiella granulomatis. There is NO pain in Ulcer & NO Lymphadenopathy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary syphilis (syphiLESS) is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a Painless genital ulcer and Painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, which are classic presentations of this sexually transmitted infection.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no: 28.8-29, 29.13-16

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 339, 341, 342

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 379-383

questions.text: Patient has problems in doing heel to shin test and repeatedly misses, and he has tremors in his hands. What is the likely site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cerebellum

 

Explanation

 

The heel-to-shin test is a classic test for cerebellar function, and difficulty or inaccuracy in performing this test indicates cerebellar dysfunction.

 

Additionally, the presence of tremors, particularly intention tremors, is characteristic of cerebellar lesions.

 

Cerebellar dysfunction can also present with other signs such as dysdiadochokinesia (difficulty with rapid alternating movements), dysmetria (inability to judge distance or scale), nystagmus, and ataxia (uncoordinated movement).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caudate: Lesions in the caudate nucleus are associated with chorea, characterized by involuntary, irregular, and unpredictable movements.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus: Lesions here typically result in dystonia and rigidity, not tremors or difficulty with the heel-to-shin test.

 

Option D. Pyramidal tract: Lesions in the pyramidal tract lead to spasticity, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, not the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebellar lesions are indicated by difficulties with coordination tests such as the heel-to-shin test, presence of intention tremors, and other signs of ataxia. Recognizing these features helps in localizing the lesion to the cerebellum.

questions.text: On Head impulse test, for a Left vestibular neuritis patient, Saccade will be in which direction? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right on left head rotation

 

In patients with left vestibular neuritis, the vestibular function on the left side is hypoactive, meaning it functions below normal levels. The head impulse test evaluates the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which helps maintain stable vision during head movements. When the head is moved to the left, the left vestibular system (which is hypoactive in this condition) should excite and the right side should inhibit. However, due to the hypoactivity on the left side, the expected response is delayed or diminished, causing the eyes to initially drift towards the hypoactive side (left) followed by corrective saccadic movements to the right. Therefore, saccades will be observed to the right during left head rotation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left on left head rotation: This is incorrect because in a left vestibular neuritis patient, the left vestibular system is hypoactive. Corrective saccades occur towards the opposite direction (right) when the hypoactive side (left) is stimulated.

 

Option B. Left on right head rotation: Incorrect because during right head rotation, the right vestibular system (which is unaffected) will function normally, leading to appropriate eye movement towards the right without corrective saccades.

 

Option D. Right on right head rotation: Incorrect because the right vestibular system is unaffected. Hence, the eyes will move correctly without saccades during right head rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In left vestibular neuritis, head impulse tests reveal saccades towards the right when the head is rotated to the left due to the hypoactive left vestibular system.

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liver

 

Explanation:

 

In the context of blast injuries, the liver is considered the least vulnerable to the direct effects of the blast wave due to its solid and dense nature. The primary blast wave from an explosion affects air-filled and delicate structures more significantly than dense, solid organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GI tract: The GI tract, especially the hollow parts, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage and perforation of the intestines.

 

Option B. Lungs: The lungs are highly vulnerable to blast injuries because they are air-filled and delicate. Blast waves can cause severe pulmonary barotrauma, leading to conditions such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pulmonary contusion.

 

Option D. Ear drum: The eardrum is extremely sensitive to the pressure changes caused by a blast wave. It is a thin membrane that can easily rupture in an explosion, making it one of the most commonly injured organs in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable organ to the primary blast wave compared to the GI tract, lungs, and eardrum, which are more susceptible due to their air-filled nature and delicate structures.

questions.text: Which drug is used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by daunorubicin? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexrazoxane

 

Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used specifically to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline chemotherapy agents like daunorubicin. It protects the heart by reducing the formation of free radicals that can damage cardiac tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aprepitant: Aprepitant is utilized to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy. It works as a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist but does not have a role in preventing cardiotoxicity from chemotherapeutic drugs.

 

Option C. Amifostine: Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent that offers protection against the toxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy on normal tissues, particularly for kidneys and salivary glands, but it is not indicated for the prevention of cardiotoxicity from daunorubicin.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. In oncology, it is often used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and to treat certain cancer-related conditions, but it is not used to prevent daunorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexrazoxane is specifically used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by anthracycline chemotherapy agents such as daunorubicin by reducing free radical formation and oxidative stress on the heart.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked as X in the given image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purkinje cells

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows a histological section of the cerebellar cortex. The cells marked with X show characteristic features of Purkinje cells:

 

  • They are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex
  • Located in the Purkinje layer (between the molecular and granular layers)
  • Organized in a single row
  • Have distinctive large cell bodies and extensive dendritic trees
  • They are the only output cells from the cerebellar cortex

 

Purkinje cells are the only cells that give output from the cerebellum, making them functionally unique and essential for cerebellar function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: Incorrect 

 

  • Because basket cells are smaller interneurons found in the molecular layer
  • They make connections with Purkinje cell bodies
  • They have a characteristic "basket-like" axonal arborization

 

Option C. Granule cells: Incorrect

 

  • Because granule cells are the smallest and most numerous neurons in the cerebellum
  • They are located in the granular layer (seen as the dense purple layer in the image)
  • They have small round cell bodies

 

Option D. Golgi cells: Incorrect

 

  • Because Golgi cells are interneurons present in the granular layer
  • They are involved in local circuit processing
  • They do not have the characteristic large cell body and location seen in the image

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex, arranged in a single layer between molecular and granular layers, and serve as the sole output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text: Warthin Finkeldey cells are seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubeola

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are a type of giant multinucleated cells that are seen in cases of measles (rubeola). Measles is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus. The virus primarily affects the respiratory system and spreads through respiratory droplets or direct contact with secretions from an infected person.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are thought to be formed due to the interaction of the measles virus with lymphoid tissue, leading to the proliferation of lymphoid cells and formation of giant cells. These cells are characterized by a central mass of nuclei surrounded by a clear halo.

 

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are not seen in rubella, rabies, or typhoid. Rubella is a viral infection that causes a mild rash and fever. Rabies is a viral infection that affects the nervous system and is usually transmitted through the bite of an infected animal. Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi and is typically transmitted through contaminated food or water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome infection will have a triad of “CCD “congenital heart disease (PDA), cataract & deafness.

 

Option C. Rabies: For rabies there should be a history of hydrophobia with history of dog bite.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid fever will have rose like spots on trunk on 7th day of fever, relative bradychardia, step ladder pattern of fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are pathognomonic giant multinucleated cells associated with measles (rubeola) infection and are indicative of viral interaction with lymphoid tissue, aiding in the diagnosis of this highly contagious respiratory illness.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Gestational hypertension

questions.text: A baby was born at 34 weeks of pregnancy; the appearance of the baby is given below. What is the mother suffering from? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a large for gestational age (LGA) fetus. Macrosomia is a condition where a newborn baby is significantly larger than average. This can often be identified by a higher birth weight and size compared to typical babies born at the same gestational age.

 

Causes of Macrosomia:

 

  1. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) and Overt Diabetes Mellitus:
    • Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia, which stimulates insulin production in the fetus. Insulin acts as a growth hormone, leading to increased fetal growth and fat deposition.
  2. Maternal Obesity:
    • Increased maternal body mass index (BMI) is associated with a higher risk of delivering a macrosomic baby.
  3. Previous Baby with Macrosomia:
    • A history of delivering a large baby increases the risk of subsequent babies also being large.
  4. Post-term Pregnancy:
    • Pregnancy extending beyond the due date increases the chance of the baby growing larger.
  5. Excessive Weight Gain in Pregnancy:
    • Significant maternal weight gain during pregnancy contributes to larger fetal size.

 

Conditions Not Associated with Macrosomia:

 

  • Anemia and Antepartum Hemorrhage (APH): These conditions are typically associated with fetal growth restriction rather than macrosomia.
  • Thrombocytopenia: This condition has no direct association with fetal weight.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Rubella: Rubella infection during pregnancy can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), not macrosomia.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism: Maternal hypothyroidism can lead to complications such as preterm birth and low birth weight but is not directly linked to macrosomia.

 

Option D. Gestational Hypertension: Gestational hypertension is associated with IUGR and preterm birth rather than increased fetal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational diabetes is a significant risk factor for macrosomia, leading to the birth of large for gestational age (LGA) babies.

 

Ref: Page no 2169, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with 400 ml urine output in 24 hours. On histology he had crescents with pauci immune glomerulonephritis. What is the main etiology? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ANCA

 

The presence of crescents in a pauci-immune glomerulonephritis pattern is characteristic of ANCA-associated vasculitis. This type of vasculitis does not typically involve immune deposits (hence "pauci-immune") and is commonly associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). These antibodies are directed against constituents of neutrophil granules and monocyte lysosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti GBM antibody: This antibody targets the glomerular basement membrane, leading to Goodpasture's syndrome, which is typically not pauci-immune.

 

Option C. Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody: This is primarily associated with primary membranous nephropathy, which shows a different histological pattern.

 

Option D. Anti-nuclear antibody: While antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, which can involve the kidneys, lupus nephritis usually shows immune complex deposition, unlike pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ANCA-associated vasculitis is linked to pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, where crescents are formed in glomeruli without significant immune deposits, differentiating it from conditions such as Goodpasture's syndrome or lupus nephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the marker of apoptosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphatidylserine

 

Phosphatidylserine is a key marker of apoptosis (programmed cell death). 

 

Under normal conditions, phosphatidylserine is located on the inner leaflet of the cell membrane.

 

 During apoptosis, it gets externalized to the outer leaflet, where it serves as a signal for phagocytes to recognize and engulf the apoptotic cell. 

 

This externalization of phosphatidylserine is one of the earliest detectable signs of apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidylethanolamine

 

  • Also known as cephalin, it is a membrane phospholipid found in cell membranes
  • While important for membrane structure, it is not a specific marker for apoptosis
  • It is involved in membrane fusion and cell signaling but not in apoptotic signaling

 

Option C. Phosphatidylcholine

 

  • Also known as lecithin
  • Major component of cell membranes and pulmonary surfactant
  • Important for membrane structure but not involved in apoptotic signaling
  • Acts as a surfactant in lungs

 

Option D. Sphingomyelin

 

  • A type of sphingolipid found in cell membranes
  • Important component of myelin sheath
  • While involved in cell signaling, it is not a specific marker for apoptosis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Phosphatidylserine externalization is a specific marker of apoptosis and its role in recognition of apoptotic cells by phagocytes.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

questions.text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age > 10 years

 

Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.

 

Leukocyte count <50,000/mm, hyperdiploidy, trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, 17 indicate a better prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), prognostic factors such as age greater than 10 years, WBC count greater than 200,000/mm^3, male gender, presence of CNS involvement, and certain cytogenetic abnormalities such as t(9;22) or t(4;11) are associated with a poorer prognosis compared to their counterparts.

choices.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complains of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step of management in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

 

 

 

The initial management for any chemical injury to the eye, including chuna (lime) exposure, is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline. This step is crucial to wash out the chemical substance from the eye to minimize further damage. Immediate irrigation helps dilute and remove the chemical agent, reducing the risk of severe injury to the ocular tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics drops in eye: Antibiotic drops are important to prevent infection after the initial management, but they are not the first step. Irrigation must be done first to remove the chemical irritant.

 

Option B. Temporary tarsorrhaphy: Temporary tarsorrhaphy involves partially sewing the eyelids together to protect the eye, but this is not appropriate in the acute phase of a chemical injury. The eye needs to remain open to allow thorough irrigation and drainage of the chemical substance.

 

Option D. Complete Scraping: Complete scraping is a procedure to remove foreign particles embedded in the eye. While this might be necessary if there are chunks of chuna embedded in the conjunctiva, it is not the first step. The initial priority is to irrigate the eye to remove as much of the chemical as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of chemical injuries to the eye is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical substance

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.
